title: What are some good books about Silicon Valley, Silicon Valley Culture, Silicon Valley Company Culture and its recent history? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the two books that best describe the recent Silicon Valley milieu of the past 10 years in unvarnished, brutally honest fashion are Chaos Monkeys, by Antonio García Martínez and Reset, by Ellen Pao. Both begin as stories of optimistic young people who came to the Valley to participate in the great internet revolution, and reveal their journey as they grapple with difficult realities. Fans of both books tend to fall into somewhat opposing cultural camps, but this is perhaps why the two books together speak some fairly uncomfortable yet illuminating truths about the Valley and what it has become (or always was). Read them both - the stories they tell are richer than what the one-dimensional reviews and critics would have you believe and you’ll find a lot of surprising insight.

Founders at Work by Jessica Livingston profiles approx 20 tech businesses from the 70s through to present day. It's a fantastic read, inspiring and you'll learn lots. Every startup founder should read this. FYI, Jessica is a partner at YC, and married to PG. http://www.amazon.com/Founders-Work-Stories-Startups-Problem-Solution/dp/1430210788/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1288400684&sr=8-1 Accidental Empires by Robert X Cringely details the rise, and animosity between Apple and Microsoft, during the 70s and 80s. It formed the basis of the TV movie, The Pirates of Silicon Valley. http://www.amazon.com/Accidental-Empires-Silicon-Millions-Competition/dp/0887308554/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1288400823&sr=1-2
